Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Past and Future Drought Variability in the Mediterranean Basin
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines the natural patterns of hydroclimate variability in the Mediterranean Basin using tree-rings, historical and paleo climate data, and modeling. The researchers will use a spatially intense multi-century to millennial-length gridded reconstruction of hydroclimate variability from North Africa to create a Mediterranean Basin Drought Atlas (MBDA) which would be compatible with similar atlases for other areas of the Northern Hemisphere. The analysis of climatic and paleoclimatic data will help identify potential linkages of Mediterranean climate variability with large-scale patterns of atmospheric and oceanic variability.

The broader impacts include international collaboration and outreach, the creation of the MBDA for the wider science community, and research of relevance to water supply issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals and objectives of our research in North Africa (NA) are to address the long-term climate variability of the Mediterranean Basin from a comparative analysis of climatic data, model simulations, and tree-ring data. A network of tree-ring chronologies (25º-42º N, 10º W-43º E) will be analyzed for information on long-term climate variability (Figure 1), associated atmosphere-ocean anomalies, and the ability of general circulation models (GCM) to reproduce drought-related features of regional climate. The work blends existing chronologies with development of new chronologies from under-sampled parts of NA to generate a Mediterranean Basin Drought Atlas that chronicles spatiotemporal drought variability over the last millennium. Reconstructions will include seasonal precipitation and drought index. The reconstructions will be analyzed for the relationship of droughts and wet periods to atmospheric circulation and sea-surface temperature anomalies.

 Activities during the period of the project (2011-2016) are: 1) Fieldwork and chronology development; 2) Precipitation (P) reconstruction and relationship to crop production; 3) Fire history reconstruction; 4) Evaluating the fidelity of the Old World Drought Atlas in North Africa; 5) Long-term context for recent drought; 6) Streamflow reconstruction for Chemora River, Algeria; 6) Assess influence of elevation on tree-ring growth; 7) Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) and tree-ring chronologies from eastern Mediterranean (EM) and NA; 8) Spatiotemporal data analysis; and 9) Reconstruction of the North Atlantic Oscillation.

Main Outcomes and Achievements are:

1) This study represents the first large-scale systematic dendroclimatic sampling focused specifically on developing chronologies from NA (Morocco, Algeria, and Tunisia) and Corsica, Italy, and Spain (Figure1). Our network of chronologies now includes 9 different species, and individual chronologies up to 1129 years in length. Archeological wood from northeastern Algeria was 14C dated to BC 700-620. This new information will spur dendroarchaeological research and serve as a backbone for dating historical structures and archaeological sites across the wider region. Data generated by this work fills critical gaps in regional and global paleoclimate databases. 

2) This network of chronologies contains coherent seasonal precipitation (P) and temperature (T) signals across a broad geographical area.

3) This is the first study investigating the relationship between tree-ring-reconstructed P and wheat production in NA. In applying dendroclimatology to agriculture, it is important to understand differences in the responses of tree growth and crops to climate.  The assessment should specifically consider crop phenology and the climate constraints on the particular crop of interest. Correlation analysis shows that tree-growth and wheat production depend similarly on monthly and seasonal P, but have contrasting patterns of dependence on T.   Our work adds a new dimension to the relationship between dendroclimatology and agricultural products

4) Developing the first fire history reconstruction using Atlantic cedar fire scarred-trees from Mount Chélia, northern Algeria. Results show that evidence for past fires often appear only on a single tree. Anthropogenic factors have played a major role in fire occurrence in the study area. Fire frequency declined dramatically in the second half of the nineteenth century with new land and forest use laws in Algeria. From a historical perspective, short-term climate conditions did not have a significant effect on fire occurrence in the study area.
